Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an Active/Adaptive Scanning Laser Microscope
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Montana State University to develop a scanning laser microscope that incorporates fast active focus control and adaptive aberration correction to provide high-quality three-dimensional microscopic images within thick living tissue or intact animals. Optical microscopy of intact tissues, coupled with the explosive advance of fluorescent markers that can be genetically encoded to specific cell types and structures, is an incredibly powerful tool for fundamental research into biological development and function. To realize the potential of this approach, however, it is necessary to improve the spatial and temporal resolution of deep-tissue imaging techniques. Microscopy of intact tissue suffers from low resolution, low contrast and poor efficiency due to deterioration of the beam focus deep in the specimen. The new microscope uses two types of deformable mirrors to control both the depth of focus and the quality of the images produced. In addition to the new microscope optics, the project also develops the necessary control algorithms and user interface to create an instrument that will be devoted to both research and research training in developmental biology and neuroscience.

The proposed instrument will facilitate research that is addressing fundamental questions about how nervous systems develop and function. While the project is specifically constructing a scanning laser microscope, the underlying technology can bring many of the same benefits to wide-field microscopes in the future. Active and adaptive optics have other potential applications, including small-format cameras and endoscopes and optical data storage read/write heads capable of high-speed focus and aberration correction with no moving lenses. The technology is therefore broadly relevant. In addition to its scientific impact the project embraces integration of research and education, training two engineering graduate students and providing cross-disciplinary research experience for several undergraduate engineering and bioscience students. A new course module will be developed that features the active/adaptive microscope as a platform to teach advanced biophotonic methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal for this project was a new scanning laser microscope for imaging deeply into intact tissue, in order to answer fundamental questions about biological development, structure and function. Traditional scanning laser microscopes provide high-speed x-y scanning, with slow z stepping to image 3D volumes. As imaging moves deeper into the tissue, aberrations limit the resolution and contrast that is possible. The innovation of this project was the incorporation of two recently developed deformable mirror technologies. One type of mirror allows fast focus control with simultaneous correction of low order aberrations (we refer to it as the woofer). Importantly, this method for focus control does not require moving the sample or any lenses, so it does not result in any unwanted vibration of the instrument. The other type of mirror corrects higher spatial frequency aberrations (we refer to it as the tweeter). The woofer and tweeter work together to modify the optical wavefront in order to preserve resolution and contrast, at any depth in the sample. Furthermore, both operate at very high speed so, now, focus depth (the z location in the 3D volume) can be controlled at speeds that are faster than the speed of the x-y scan. While previous microscopes used deformable mirrors to correct aberrations at a particular depth, the correction could not be optimized over the full image plane and updated on-the-fly during x-y scanning. This instrument does that. The result of our project is a new instrument with optimized (corrected) image resolution throughout a 3D volume, and with agile scanning that allows imaging along user-defined surfaces within the sample. The instrument will be located in a shared-use microscopy facility at Montana State University.

 

This was a successful instrument development project that led to several publications, especially related to the use of active mirror devices to improve the performance and versatility of high resolution, high NA laser scanning microscopes. It also advanced the underlying deformable mirror technologies and the performance of those technologies relative to the demands of on-the-fly focus control and aberration management. A significant outcome for the project was the education and training of ten different students, including 5 graduate students and 5 undergraduate students, who contributed to the development effort. Importantly, these are engineering students who are gaining exposure to and appreciation for challenging problems in the biological sciences. In the future we will continue to use this instrument as a platform for research, and to train students about both biology and the important underlying technologies that allow us to see living biological systems with subcellular resolution.
